Government give companies subsidies to take on interns to give them the training they require. Interns in turn, get an allowance. They never get a salary. It's called an allowance because, they are still in the learning process.

The government gives out subsidies and tax cuts as incentives for companies to take on interns. For big companies it's a good way to headhunt new talent. I have hired interns who finished as I have spend time training them and they did well.

Employers see it the other way around. They would be asking "why am I paying to teach these students? That's the job of the university." Big companies who can afford it do give bigger allowances. But smaller companies will not give an allowance bigger than the subsidies they get

Proposed taxes on real estate in Budget 2022/23:   Those owning more than one immovable properties (any property) worth Rs.25 million or more will be taxed at 1% of imaginary income that will be 5% of the fair market value of property. One personal home will be exempt (3/3)

3) FLL "Entry 47:Taxes on income other than agricultural income-Entry 50:Taxes on capital value of assets, not including taxes on immovable property". Therefore, proposal to tax immovable property through deemed income-is commendable but clearly in violation of Constitution n/4

Since we're talking about inflation rates la, you know Malaysia's current inflation rate stands at 2.8% (May) and that's because a lot of the main consumer products on sale are subsidized (chicken, oil & gas, cooking oil etc)  It would be much higher if we did not have subsidies.

That comes to show inflation rates are not accurate indicators of the general economic situation in countries.  You can be a country with significantly low rates, and that would be due to the country spending more on subsidies.
The problem with this is goes back to the usual Economics catchphrase, "There is no free lunch." 🙂  You want subsidies to lower inflation, you still need to incur government spending.

Relation between GST and supply:  We can say that, supply is the gateway of GST. No supply, no GST. But all supplies are not taxed. Supplies chargeable to GST i.e "Scope of supply" is defined u/s.7 of CGST Act 2017. Any transaction outside the scope of supply is outside GST also.

@PMOIndia @FinMinIndia I found something today while calculating my expenses. More than 60% of my salary goes to the government every month. 1. First they deduct income tax on my salary. 2. Then with the remaining amount I buy groceries in which they deduct GST.

In a recent ruling, AAR (MP) ruled that, "Ber Berry"( crushed berphal packed) is classifiable under GST Tariff heading 2008 with 12% tax. AAR observed that the process exceeds the process covered by chapter8 that covers fresh fruit or fruit cooked by steaming or boiling in water.
3. Then I buy clothes for my kids and they deduct GST. 4. Then I travel to my hometown and I pay heavy toll in the highways. 5. Then I buy electronics for my personal use and they deduct GST
6. Then due to bad roads in Bangalore my car and bike needs to be serviced and they deduct heavy GST for the spare parts. 7. Then I go to buy medicine for my family and they deduct GST.

8. Then I buy a house after paying heavy registration charges to the government, I still pay property tax every year. 9. We get water from government after paying the water bill. 10. Then we go to hotel to eat food and they deduct GST.

land and again pays GST for the fees paid. Next for the services rendered by the builder's contractors for excavation and for the plinth work GST is paid by the builder to the Government. Again when he is busy with the slab work and constructing the building and/or tower, he 3/n

#GujaratKiBaat Serving the marginalised has been at the core of the policies of the Government of Gujarat. The budget for the welfare of Scheduled Castes was increased from Rs. 101.7 crores in 2002 to Rs. 1,094.33 crores in 2022.  via NaMo App

#GujaratKiBaat The financial allocation in the last 20 years in the budget for the holistic development of women has increased. From Rs. 158 crores, Rs 3511 crores was allocated in the year 2022-23, a massive increase in the budget. via NaMo App

#GujaratKiBaat The Gujarat govt. made the budgetary provision of ₹ 2,656.4 crores for the overall development of tribals in the year 2021-22 against the budget of ₹ 100.8 crores in 2002-03. This is a 26-fold increase in the budget! via NaMo App
